result.execSummary:
The defendant Michael J. Vandenbergh was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Bail Jumping-Felony, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(b).
  • Theft-Movable Property <=$2500, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Concurrent with: Any probation now serving

miscConds.notes:
If agent recommends, defendant must attend and successfully complete an alcohol assessment and comply with any recommended treatment.  Defendant is to execute any releases necessary for agent to verify compliance.

Defendant to be subject to random testing by his agent.

If agent recommends, defendant must attend and successfully complete a drug assessment, and comply with any recommended treatment.  Defendant to execute any releases necessary for agent to verify compliance.

Defendant to be subject to random testing by his agent.

The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions. 

DNA already on file.
Defendant shall have no contact, directly or indirectly, either personally, by mail, telephone or through any other person, or by any other means with the following business: Tri-R Car Wash.

If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt. Must pay all costs of supervision and court ordered financial obligations during the term of probation.

Must seek and maintain full-time employment or a combination of employment and education which is satisfactory to your probation agent.  Defendant  must not leave or change employment without prior approval of your probation agent.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Michael J. Vandenbergh

records.addlTxt: Return to sender. Not deliverable as addressed. Unable to forward. JOC's

Court questioned defendant on his understanding of the waiver of preliminary hearing.  He stated he understood.  Court found that the defendant knowingly and intelligently waived his right to have a preliminary hearing. BOT, waive formal reading of the complaints.

3:29 PM Defendant Michael J. Vandenbergh appeared by video, in custody of La Crosse County jail.  Attorney Carly June Sebion in court for Michael J. Vandenbergh.  Attorney Crystal Leigh Jensen in court for State of Wisconsin.  Defendant agrees to appear remotely. State is in victim compliance.  Defendant pleads No Contest to count 1 and count 2 in 22CF76.  Pleads No Contest to count 2 in 22CF77.  Remaining charges DRI. 

Court reviewed the elements and potential penalties of the charge the defendant plead to.  He understood.   Court reviewed the plea questionnaire, constitutional rights and elements with the defendant. Felony warnings given.  He understood. Defense stipulated that there is a factual basis for the plea.   Court found that the defendant freely, voluntarily, knowingly and intelligently entered his plea and waived his constitutional rights.  Court found that a factual basis exists for the plea.  Found guilty of count 1 Bail Jumping-Felony (1) contrary to 946.49(1)(b);  count 2 Theft-Movable Property (1) contrary to 943.20(1)(a);  count 2 Theft-Movable Property (1) contrary to 943.20(1)(a).  All other charges DRI. Defendant exercised his right to allocution. 

Victim in case 22CF76 is present in the court room, doesn't wish to make a statement.

Joint recommendation of sentence withheld, 2 years probation with conditions: Costs, DNA already on file, Risk/needs assessment and programming recommended, no contact with Tri-R Car Wash, Restitution of $4,462.36 plus 10%, 30 days conditional jail on Count 2 in case 22CF76.  Not sure of the credit as of yet.

Court adopts the joint recommendation orders sentence with held place on probation for 2 years with conditions (concurrent with all 3 counts in both cases):  Risk/needs assessment and programming, no contact with Tri-R Car Wash 22CF76, 22CF77 no contact with victim, Restitution of $4,462.36 plus 10% in 22CF76, court costs, DNA requirement, seek and maintain employment.  Set up a payment plan to pay restitution within the 2 year probation period.  If there are no prohibitions ordered through treatment court stating not to have employment, AODA.  Count 2 22CF76- 30days of conditional jail can serve in La Crosse County if they will allow it, begins now.
